question_details.title: Will SpaceX's Fram2 mission launch before April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: [SpaceX to launch privately-financed international crew of four around Earth’s poles](https://spaceflightnow.com/2024/08/12/spacex-to-launch-privately-financed-international-crew-of-four-around-earths-poles/) At the time of this question the mission is tentatively [scheduled](https://www.space.com/32286-space-calendar.html) for March 2025.
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if SpaceX's [Fram2 mission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fram2) launches before April 1, 2025?
question_details.fine_print: For purposes of this question "launch" [is defined](https://science.nasa.gov/learn/basics-of-space-flight/chapter14-1/) using the following from Nasa: "The launch of a spacecraft comprises a period of powered flight during which the vehicle rises above Earth's atmosphere and accelerates at least to orbital velocity."

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Intuitive Machines-2 Lifts Off - NASA**
A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying Intuitive Machines' Nova-C lunar lander (IM-2) successfully launched from NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida on February 26, 2025. The lander is scheduled to land on the Moon on March 6, where it will conduct NASA science and technology demonstrations to support future human missions. The Lunar Trailblazer spacecraft, which launched as a rideshare with the IM-2 mission, is also en route to lunar orbit, where it will map the distribution of different forms of water on the Moon, according to NASA.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 05:34 PM
Source:[NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/image-article/intuitive-machines-2-lifts-off/)

**SpaceX Launches Athena Lunar Lander on IM-2 Mission**
SpaceX launched the Athena lunar lander from Florida's Kennedy Space Center on February 27, 2025, as part of the IM-2 mission. The lander, developed by Intuitive Machines, is carrying a payload for NASA, including the Polar Resources Ice Mining Experiment 1 (PRIME-1) which will drill up to 1 meter deep to search for water ice or other volatile compounds. The lander is similar to the company's previous IM-1 or Odysseus, but has been modified to address issues from the previous mission, including a faulty laser altimeter. Athena is also carrying several commercial payloads, including the Micro Nova Hopper, which will hop around the lunar surface using its own propulsion system. The lander is expected to land on the Mons Muntus plateau in the lunar south pole on March 6. 'It's a great day,' said a SpaceX spokesperson, as the company continues to push the boundaries of lunar exploration.
Original language: uk
Publish date: February 27, 2025 06:42 AM
Source:[УКРІНФОРМ](https://www.ukrinform.ua/rubric-world/3964923-spacex-vidpravila-na-misac-privatnij-posadkovij-aparat.html)

**SpaceX's IM-2 Mission: A Step Towards Lunar Resource Utilization**
The IM-2 mission, launched on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from the Kennedy Space Center, aims to land the Athenea module on March 6 in Mons Mouton, a crater in the lunar south pole that never receives sunlight. Scientists believe these craters are filled with tons of ice, which can be converted by future astronauts into drinking water, breathable air, and even fuel for rockets. If successful, it will be the second time a SpaceX spacecraft has landed on the Moon, following the Odysseus mission, which landed smoothly on February 22, 2024. According to NASA, the mission will search for water and other volatile substances on the lunar surface. As explained by NASA, the mission is crucial for the Artemis program and a program aimed at preparing future human missions to the Moon and Mars. One of the main goals of IM-2 is to demonstrate the extraction and use of resources found on the Moon. The mission will deploy a drill and a mass spectrometer to analyze the possible presence of gases and volatiles in the lunar soil in Mons Mouton. Additionally, a passive laser reflector will be installed as a permanent reference point for future missions. Other technologies on board the module include a surface communication system and a motorized drone capable of moving across the lunar terrain through short jumps. Along with the IM-2 mission, NASA will also launch a probe that will enter lunar orbit to map the distribution of water on the surface. NASA plans to send astronauts back to the Moon's surface in 2026, including the first woman and the first African American, in another expedition to the south pole region, where frozen water is expected to exist.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 27, 2025 04:14 AM
Source:[SAPO](https://www.sapo.pt/noticias/economia/empresa-privada-dos-estados-unidos-lanca_67bfe1e8c5200e7493b01b5c)

**Watch: SpaceX launches third Moon mission of 2025 with Athena lander aboard Falcon 9 - The Times of India**
SpaceX successfully launched its third Moon landing mission of 2025, IM-2, carrying the Athena lander atop a Falcon 9 rocket. The mission, led by Intuitive Machines, aims to explore lunar ice deposits near the Moon's south pole with a suite of scientific experiments, including Nasa payloads. According to the article, the company aims for a more stable touchdown this time, unlike its predecessor which landed but tipped over. If successful, IM-2 will further solidify the role of private companies in lunar exploration, supporting NASA's Artemis programme, which aims to return humans to the Moon later this decade.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 12:32 AM
Source:[The Times of India](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/watch-spacex-launches-third-moon-mission-of-2025-with-athena-lander-aboard-falcon-9-im-2/articleshow/118589657.cms)

**SpaceX launches third Moon landing mission of 2025 with Athena lander atop Falcon 9**
SpaceX successfully launched the IM-2 mission, the third Moon landing mission of 2025, carrying the 'Athena' Nova-C class lunar lander. The mission, spearheaded by Intuitive Machines, aims to gather critical data about the lunar surface, particularly in the region of Mons Mouton. The Athena lander's destination, Mons Mouton, is a crucial target for gathering data that will inform future human missions to the Moon. The mission includes two lunar mobility vehicles and key instruments such as the Polar Resources Ice Mining Experiment-1 (PRIME-1) suite and the Laser Retroreflector Array (LRA). The mission is expected to analyse the lunar soil's composition and search for evidence of water ice, with the goal of establishing a long-term human presence on the Moon.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 12:22 AM
Source:[India Today](https://www.indiatoday.in/science/story/elon-musks-spacex-launches-third-moon-landing-mission-of-2025-with-im-2-athena-lander-atop-falcon-9-rocket-2686195-2025-02-27)

**SpaceX Falcon 9 Prepares for Historic Lunar Mission Launch**
A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket is set to launch on February 26, 2025, at 7:16 p.m. EST from Kennedy Space Center, carrying the Intuitive Machines' lunar lander, Athena, equipped with NASA scientific instruments. The IM-2 mission aims to advance lunar exploration as part of NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) initiative and Artemis campaign. According to a SpaceX spokesperson, 'We are enthusiastic about the IM-2 mission laying the groundwork for future lunar exploration and the Artemis program.' The lander will conduct on-site demonstrations of resource utilization on the lunar surface, assess the presence of volatiles in lunar soil, and provide a permanent reference point for future spacecraft. The mission will also include a surface communications system, a propulsive drone, and several non-NASA payloads. Live launch coverage will be available on NASA platforms, and public participation will include virtual attendance and social media engagement.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[timesng.com](https://timesng.com/spacex-falcon-prepares/)

**Falcon 9 launches second lunar mission of 2025 with IM-2 lander**
SpaceX launched the Intuitive Machines IM-2 mission, a lunar lander mission that includes several secondary payloads, on February 26, 2025. The mission aims to explore the lunar south polar region and search for water ice deposits. The IM-2 lander, named Athena, is equipped with a 36 kg NASA experiment package known as PRIME-1, which includes a robotic drill and a mass spectrometer to analyze lunar regolith and search for water. The lander will also deploy two small lunar rovers and a lunar hopper to explore the surface. The mission is expected to last ten days before the lunar night begins, and Athena will have the opportunity to observe a total solar eclipse on March 14. Intuitive Machines plans to fly two more NOVA-C landers, each with a payload capacity of around 130 kg, to the lunar surface in the 2025-2026 timeframe.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 09:23 PM
Source:[nasaspaceflight.com](https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2025/02/im-2-launch/)

**Private Mission IM-2 to Search for Water Ice on the Moon**
Despite the challenges facing the US space program, a private mission, IM-2, is set to launch towards the Moon on February 26-27, 2025, aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. The mission aims to search for water ice in the lunar south pole, a region rich in resources, which could be suitable for the Artemis program and even the construction of a lunar base in the coming years. 'This area seems to be rich in resources due to the permanently shaded craters,' explains Pierre-Yves Meslin, a planetary researcher at the IRAP. 'This environment is ideal for trapping volatile elements like hydrogen, which could be present in large quantities.' The IM-2 mission is equipped with a drill called Trident, which will dig 1 meter deep, and a mass spectrometer, MSolo, designed to analyze the composition of the sample and find water ice. Casey Honniball, a NASA researcher, hopes that IM-2 will help to lift some of the uncertainties about the Moon: 'There are enormous uncertainties about the Moon. We are particularly interested in water, but we do not know how much it is present, if it is on the surface or in the soil, or how it is distributed across the Moon.' However, IM-2 faces several challenges, including the limitations of its spectrometer and the fragility of water ice, which risks sublimating during the drilling operation.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 26, 2025 06:05 PM
Source:[Le Monde.fr](https://www.lemonde.fr/sciences/article/2025/02/26/la-nasa-part-a-la-recherche-de-l-eau-de-la-lune-a-l-aide-d-une-mission-privee_6565589_1650684.html)

**SpaceX Falcon 9 launch Aims for the Moon and Beyond**
A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket is scheduled to launch from Kennedy Space Center on February 26, carrying multiple payloads, including lunar-bound hardware and asteroid mining technology. The mission aims to support future lunar bases and resource utilization strategies. The payloads include the Nova-C lander, named Athena, designed to search for water and other chemical components on the Moon's South Pole region, and the Odin spacecraft, built by Astroforge, which will attempt to mine an asteroid called 2022 OB5. According to Astroforge CEO Matt Gialich, the mission is taking 'extraordinary risks' and has a 'far lower likelihood of success.' However, if successful, the mission could mark a shift in humanity's reach beyond Earth and potentially lead to the establishment of a moon base in the future.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 06:04 PM
Source:[archyde.com](https://www.archyde.com/stacked-spacex-launch-pioneering-science-on-a-lunar-mission-to-beyond/)

**Falcon 9 Lands in the Bahamas for the First Time**
For the first time, the first stage of a Falcon 9 rocket has landed outside of the United States, in the Bahamas. During the Starlink-10.12 mission, the booster landed on the Just Read The Instructions barge, located within the Bahamas archipelago. The Falcon 9 launched from Cape Canaveral's launch complex 40 on February 19, 2025, at 00:21 UTC. After approximately 8 minutes and 15 seconds, the first stage landed on the barge, while about an hour later, the second stage released 23 Starlink V2 Mini satellites into orbit. This new landing site is a strategic point for SpaceX, offering several benefits, including maximizing the performance of the Falcon 9 rocket and optimizing the payload it can carry into orbit. As stated by SpaceX, 'This new trajectory will be used for the Fram2 mission, during which an astronaut will fly over both the North and South Poles for the first time.'
Original language: it
Publish date: February 19, 2025 10:55 AM
Source:[astrospace.it](https://www.astrospace.it/2025/02/19/per-la-prima-volta-il-primo-stadio-di-un-falcon-9-e-atterrato-alle-bahamas/)

**NASA-SpaceX capsule switch poised to bring Starliner astronauts home days sooner**
NASA has swapped out the astronaut capsule it plans to use for an upcoming routine flight to the International Space Station, allowing a slightly earlier return for two Starliner astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams. The decision moves up the Crew-10 launch to March 12, from the previous target of March 25. NASA said it would still need to do a flight readiness assessment of the previously flown Crew Dragon capsule, named Endeavor, which has been used on three previous missions. The move follows President Donald Trump's demand to SpaceX CEO Elon Musk to bring Wilmore and Williams back to Earth 'as soon as possible.' NASA's Commercial Crew Program head Steve Stich said, 'Human spaceflight is full of unexpected challenges,' praising SpaceX for its flexibility. The spacecraft swap affects SpaceX's planned Fram2 private astronaut mission, which will use a different Crew Dragon in SpaceX's fleet. The Crew-10 decision is also expected to impact Axiom's planned Crew Dragon mission where it will fly government astronauts from India, Poland, and Hungary.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2025 12:17 AM
Source:[The Straits Times](https://www.straitstimes.com/world/nasa-spacex-capsule-switch-poised-to-bring-starliner-astronauts-home-days-sooner)

**2025年宇宙開発の未来図**
In 2025, several notable space missions are scheduled to take place, including the launch of the HTV-X spacecraft, the first human spaceflight mission of the Crew-10 spacecraft, and the debut of the Dream Chaser spacecraft. The HTV-X spacecraft will be used for resupply missions to the International Space Station (ISS) and will feature a new technology for removing carbon dioxide from the air. The Crew-10 spacecraft will carry JAXA astronaut Takuya Onishi to the ISS, where he will conduct research on the effects of gravity on cancer treatment and the removal of carbon dioxide from the air. The Dream Chaser spacecraft, developed by Sierra Space, will make its first flight in May 2025 and will be used for resupply missions to the ISS. The spacecraft will feature a lifting body design and will be capable of carrying cargo and passengers. In addition, the Fram2 mission, a private spaceflight mission led by SpaceX and entrepreneur Chun Wang, will take place in March 2025. The mission will be the first to fly to an extreme orbit and will feature a crew of three. The Vast Space company is also planning to launch its Haven-1 spacecraft in August 2025, which will be used for resupply missions to the ISS. The spacecraft will feature a solar panel and communication equipment and will be capable of carrying four people for up to 30 days. India is also planning to launch its Gaganyaan spacecraft in 2025, which will be used for human spaceflight missions. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying three people to an altitude of 400 km and will feature a lifting body design. The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is also planning to launch its LVM3 rocket, which will be used for human spaceflight missions. The rocket will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 4,000 kg to an altitude of 400 km. The ISRO is also planning to launch its Gaganyaan spacecraft in 2026, which will be used for human spaceflight missions. The spacecraft will feature a lifting body design and will be capable of carrying three people to an altitude of 400 km. The ISRO is also planning to launch its LVM3 rocket in 2025, which will be used for human spaceflight missions. The rocket will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 4,000 kg to an altitude of 400 km. As the number of private space companies increases, the space industry is becoming more competitive and exciting. The future of space development is uncertain, but one thing is clear: the next few years will be an exciting time for space exploration.
Original language: ja
Publish date: January 25, 2025 01:05 AM
Source:[マイナビニュース](https://news.mynavi.jp/techplus/article/aerospace2025-3/)

**150 Launches projected for Florida’s Space Coast in 2025**
Space Florida CEO and President Rob Long expects a significant increase in launches from Florida's Space Coast in 2025, with approximately 150 launches projected. This includes both government and commercial launches, such as the first flight of Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket, scheduled for no earlier than this Sunday. Additionally, NASA's SpaceX Crew-10 and Crew-11 missions, the private Axiom Mission 4, and the FRAM-2 Mission are also planned for the year. Long stated, 'I think we're just going to continue to accelerate our pace.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: January 11, 2025 02:00 AM
Source:[wftv.com](https://www.wftv.com/news/local/150-launches-projected-floridas-space-coast-2025/NGOR7UVNSZHXXEONMRH37BPK6E/)

**SpaceX and Blue Origin to Launch Orbital Rockets and Spacecraft in 2025**
The new year of space exploration will begin with the launches of orbital rockets and spacecraft by two entrepreneurs, Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos, who are now engaged in a fierce competition in the satellite market. SpaceX is planning to conduct another test flight of its massive Starship vehicle in early January, with the goal of reusing the booster and releasing some Starlink satellites. The reusability and high cargo capacity of the Starship represent the main strengths for drastically reducing launch costs. After this test, SpaceX plans an even more ambitious flight, aimed at demonstrating the ability to transfer propellant between two Starship vehicles in Earth orbit, a crucial step for testing the ability to use this spacecraft in future missions to the Moon and Mars. Blue Origin, on the other hand, will launch its orbital rocket New Glenn in January, which will become the primary launch vehicle for the over 3,000 satellites of the Kuiper internet constellation of Amazon. The entry of Blue Origin into the heavy launcher market will consolidate the role of Jeff Bezos' company as a direct competitor to SpaceX. The European Space Agency (ESA) will also be a protagonist in 2025 with the launch of the Space Rider, scheduled for the third quarter. This spacecraft will spend two months in Earth orbit, during which it will automatically conduct technological demonstrations and experiments in microgravity conditions. At the end of the mission, the Space Rider will return to Earth, landing on a runway at the European spaceport in French Guiana. Designed by the ESA, the spacecraft can be reused for at least five flights and represents an important step towards continuous and cost-effective access to Earth orbit. Human space exploration will continue to play a central role in 2025, with SpaceX launching a new commercial mission with the Crew Dragon capsule. The mission, known as FRAM2, will take four private explorers to a polar orbit, a trajectory never before traversed by crewed vehicles. The mission will be led by polar explorer Chun Wang and will include filmmaker Jannicke Mikkelsen, polar explorer Eric Philips, and engineer/scientist Rabea Rogge. Axiom Space will continue its commercial missions to the International Space Station (ISS) in the coming months, with Axiom-4, the fourth crewed mission, using the Crew Dragon to take four astronauts to the ISS, where they will spend a decade conducting various scientific experiments. This mission represents another step towards the realization of the AxStation, a private space station initially connected to the ISS but destined to operate autonomously. The space station could host both private and institutional activities and represent the future of orbital exploration after 2030, when the ISS will be decommissioned. 2025 will also be a year of direct ventures beyond Earth's orbit, with Firefly Aerospace launching the Ghost Riders in the Sky mission in January, designed to land an automatic vehicle that carries a decade of NASA experiments on the Moon. The landing is expected in a region formed by ancient volcanic eruptions dating back over three billion years. The Blue Ghost 1 lander will operate for an entire lunar day (about 14 Earth days), collecting data on the lunar surface and the interaction with the solar wind, the flow of charged particles emitted by the Sun. In February, it will be the turn of the automatic Intuitive Machines-2 (IM-2) mission, which will continue the work of the previous IM-1. Despite the rollover that occurred at the time of landing, IM-1 represented the first lunar landing of a spacecraft built by a private company. IM-2 will also land at the South Pole, carrying a drill and a mass spectrometer to examine the composition of the lunar subsurface. The mission also includes the release of the small Lunar Trailblazer satellite, designed to remain in orbit and map the deposits of water ice present at the South Pole lunar. These data will be fundamental for NASA in planning future Artemis missions, which will return astronauts to the Moon over half a century after the successes of the Apollo program.
Original language: it
Publish date: January 06, 2025 06:16 PM
Source:[HuffPost Italia](https://www.huffingtonpost.it/blog/2025/01/06/news/dal_web_alle_stelle_musk_vs_bezos_sfida_spaziale_del_2025-18121224/)

**German Astronaut Rabea Rogge Trains for Historic Space Mission**
German researcher Rabea Rogge is preparing for her spaceflight as part of the 'Fram2' mission, which is scheduled for spring 2025. Rogge, 28, from Berlin, will be the first German woman in space. The mission will involve a three to five-day flight over the polar regions of the Earth on a Falcon-9 rocket. According to Rogge, 'Fram2' will have a completely new orbit. The mission will be a significant milestone for Rogge and Germany's space program. Rogge is currently undergoing intense training in a SpaceX training capsule, where she is rehearsing various scenarios and their responses. She says, 'The launch on a US-American Falcon-9 rocket is planned for spring 2025.' 
Original language: de
Publish date: January 06, 2025 12:19 PM
Source:[computerbild.de](https://www.computerbild.de/artikel/cb-News-Internet-Weltraum-Start-2025-Deutsche-Astronautin-Rabea-Rogge-trainiert-fuer-All-39316781.html)

**The Future of Space Tourism Begins in 2025: What Can We Expect?**
The year 2025 promises to be exciting for space tourism, with numerous innovative projects expanding the horizons of space travel. In the stratosphere, at an altitude of about 30 kilometers, passengers will experience the darkness of space and the curvature of the Earth. This experience will be accessible to a wider audience, allowing many people to live an unprecedented adventure and appreciate the beauty of our planet from impressive altitudes. Two French companies, Zephalto and Stratoflight, are leading the way in stratospheric flights. Zephalto, which successfully completed a manned test flight in October 2024, plans to start commercial operations this year, integrating a scientific dimension. Stratoflight is developing an innovative stratospheric transportation system, featuring a capsule with an external platform that allows passengers to exit into space. Axiom Space is planning two missions with SpaceX, including AX-4, which will transport a crew of four astronauts, including a member of the Indian Space Agency, a Hungarian astronaut, and a Polish astronaut from the European Space Agency. SpaceX is also planning two crew rotations, including Crew-10 in March and Crew-11 in July. The company is also preparing to launch FRAM2, its first human mission to polar orbit, to observe the Earth. This private mission, which will not be touristical, will carry a crew of four people and a payload. The main objective is to conduct a scientific program on atmospheric interactions, the study of light phenomena, and astronaut health. Another promising project for 2025 is the launch of the Vast company's habitable module, Haven-1, which will be transported on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. This station, although small, will offer a habitable volume of 45 cubic meters and can accommodate up to four astronauts for a 30-day stay.
Original language: fr
Publish date: January 06, 2025 10:33 AM
Source:[Futura](https://www.futura-sciences.com/sciences/actualites/vols-habites-avenir-tourisme-spatial-commence-2025-peut-on-vraiment-attendre-118632/)

**Rabea Rogge Trains for Historic Space Mission in 2025**
Rabea Rogge, a 28-year-old German researcher from Berlin, is training for her space mission in 2025, which would make her the first German woman in space. The mission, named 'Fram2', will involve a three to five-day flight on a US-American Falcon-9 rocket, where the four-person team will fly over the polar regions of the Earth. Rogge explained that 'Fram2' will have a completely new orbit. She will be responsible for investigating a mysterious celestial phenomenon in the polar regions. Rogge has been training in a SpaceX capsule for months, where she has been rehearsing various scenarios and their reactions. She will also be taking a Gedenkmedaille (commemorative medal) of Otto Lilienthal and a small replica of the Berlin-Schöneberg town hall's Freedom Bell with her on the flight. Rogge said that she admires the calmness of other astronauts, particularly those from NASA, and hopes to maintain her composure during the mission.

Publish date: January 04, 2025 10:00 AM

**Space Industry Expectations for 2025**
Several significant events are expected in the space industry in 2025. SpaceX is planning to launch 25 Starship missions, with the goal of achieving 25% more fuel capacity and making the spacecraft reusable. The company is also working on the Artemis program, which aims to send humans to the Moon and Mars. Another notable project is the New Glenn rocket, developed by Blue Origin, which is expected to debut in 2025. The rocket will have a reusable first stage and will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 12 tons to low Earth orbit. The Neutron rocket, developed by Rocket Lab, is also expected to debut in 2025. The rocket will have a unique design, with a deployable fairing that will allow it to carry a payload of up to 8 tons to low Earth orbit. The Dream Chaser spacecraft, developed by Sierra Space, is expected to make its first flight in 2025. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 5.5 tons to the International Space Station and will be reusable. The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is planning to launch the Gaganyaan spacecraft in 2025, which will carry a crew of four astronauts to the International Space Station. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 7 tons to low Earth orbit. The Fram2 spacecraft, developed by Chuan Van, is expected to launch in 2025 and will carry a crew of four astronauts to the International Space Station. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 10 tons to low Earth orbit. The Vast company is planning to launch the Haven-1 space station in 2025, which will be a reusable space station that will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 14 tons to low Earth orbit. The SPHEREx telescope is expected to launch in 2025 and will be capable of measuring the redshift of 450 million galaxies, which will help scientists understand the evolution of the universe. The telescope will also be used to search for the origin of water in planetary systems. The Resilience spacecraft, developed by ispace, is expected to launch in 2025 and will carry a payload of scientific instruments to the Moon. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 10 kg to the Moon's surface. The Blue Ghost spacecraft, developed by Firefly Aerospace, is expected to launch in 2025 and will carry a payload of scientific instruments to the Moon. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 94 kg to the Moon's surface. The IM-2 spacecraft, developed by Intuitive Machines, is expected to launch in 2025 and will carry a payload of scientific instruments to the Moon. The spacecraft will be capable of carrying a payload of up to 10 kg to the Moon's surface. The Micro-Nova spacecraft, developed by Intuitive Machines, is expected to launch in 2025 and will be the first lunar drone. **Berlin Resident Rabea Rogge Trains for Historic Space Mission in 2025**
German researcher Rabea Rogge is training intensively to become the first German woman in space. She will be flying on a SpaceX Falcon-9 rocket in the spring of 2025 as part of the 'Fram2' mission, which will take her and a three-person team over the polar regions of the Earth in a three to five day mission. According to Rogge, 'Fram2' will have a completely new orbit. **SpaceX Completes 2024 Launch Schedule with Starlink 12 Mission**
SpaceX has completed its 2024 launch schedule by deploying a new batch of Starlink V2 Mini satellites, some of which are equipped with direct-to-cell technology, into orbit. The Starlink 12 mission was launched on December 31 from Kennedy Space Center's Launch Complex 39A in Florida, marking the 132nd and final launch of the year for SpaceX. The Falcon 9 rocket carried 21 Starlink satellites into a low Earth orbit, with 13 of them featuring direct-to-cell capabilities, enhancing connectivity in remote areas. The mission was initially scheduled for December 30 but was delayed due to launch preparations. The Falcon 9 rocket, B1078, completed its 16th mission, which included previous missions such as Crew-6, USSF-124, and 11 Starlink missions. The rocket successfully landed on a drone ship in the Atlantic Ocean, marking the 104th landing on that specific ship and the 390th landing in SpaceX's history. SpaceX aims to increase its launch cadence in 2025, with planned missions including two commercial crew flights, Fram-2 and Ax-4, and two NASA crew missions. The company also plans to expand its customer base while continuing to grow its Starlink constellation.
Original language: ar
Publish date: December 31, 2024 04:56 PM
Source:[nafeza2world.com](https://www.nafeza2world.com/Tknwlwjya/2038665)

**SpaceX Concludes 2024 with Successful Starlink Launch**
SpaceX has concluded its 2024 launch schedule by deploying a new batch of 21 Starlink V2 Mini satellites, some of which are equipped with direct-to-cell technology, into orbit. The Starlink 12 mission, launched on December 31 from Kennedy Space Center's Pad 39A in Florida, marks the 132nd and final launch of the year for SpaceX, a significant achievement in its efforts to expand global internet access. The Falcon 9 rocket carried 21 broadband satellites into a low-Earth orbit, with 13 of them featuring direct-to-cell capabilities, enhancing connectivity in remote areas. The mission was initially set for December 30 but was delayed due to launch preparations. The Falcon 9 rocket, B1078, completed its 16th mission, which included previous missions such as Crew-6, USSF-124, and 11 Starlink missions. The rocket successfully landed on a drone ship in the Atlantic Ocean, marking the 104th landing on that particular ship and the 390th overall in SpaceX history. SpaceX aims to increase its launch cadence in 2025, with planned missions including two commercial crew flights, Fram-2 and Ax-4, and two NASA crewed missions. The company also plans to expand its customer base while continuing to grow its Starlink constellation.
Original language: ar
Publish date: December 31, 2024 04:02 PM
Source:[gulf365.net](https://news.gulf365.net/technology/12896727/%D8%AA%D9%83%D9%86%D9%88%D9%84%D9%88%D8%AC%D9%8A%D8%A7-SpaceX-%D8%AA%D8%AE%D8%AA%D8%AA%D9%85-2024-%D8%A8%D8%A5%D8%B7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%82-21-%D9%82%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%8B-%D8%B5%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%8B-%D9%85%D9%86-Starlink.html)

The Falcon 9 rocket carried 21 Starlink satellites into a low-Earth orbit, with 13 of them featuring direct-to-cell capabilities, enhancing connectivity in remote areas. The mission was initially scheduled for December 30 but was delayed due to launch preparations. The Falcon 9 rocket, B1078, completed its 16th mission, which included previous missions such as Crew-6, USSF-124, and 11 Starlink missions. **SpaceX Completes 2024 Launch Schedule with Starlink 12 Mission**
SpaceX has completed its launch schedule for 2024 by deploying a new batch of Starlink V2 Mini satellites, some of which are equipped with direct-to-cell technology, into orbit. The Starlink 12 mission was launched on December 31 from Kennedy Space Center's Launch Complex 39A in Florida, marking the 132nd and final launch of the year for SpaceX. The Falcon 9 rocket carried 21 Starlink satellites into a low Earth orbit, with 13 of them featuring direct-to-cell capabilities, enhancing connectivity in remote areas. The mission was originally scheduled for December 30 but was delayed due to launch preparations. The Falcon 9 rocket, B1078, completed its 16th mission, which included previous missions such as Crew-6, USSF-124, and 11 Starlink missions. The rocket successfully landed on a drone ship in the Atlantic Ocean, marking the 104th landing on that particular ship and the 390th landing overall for SpaceX. SpaceX aims to increase its launch cadence in 2025, with planned missions including two commercial crew flights, Fram-2 and Ax-4, and two NASA crewed missions, as well as expanding its customer base and continuing to grow its Starlink constellation.
